Key Arguments: The proposed Bill will undermine democracy and the public's right to debate and discuss issues without censorship.
The terms 'misinformation' and 'disinformation' are subjective and can be weaponized to suppress dissenting views.
The Bill exempts the government and certain organizations from the same obligations, allowing them to spread misinformation.
Diversity of thought strengthens society and should not be penalized through censorship.
There is no evidence that public expression on social media has led to significant negative consequences.
Historical examples show that what is considered misinformation at one time may later be proven true.
Main Themes: Historical context and lessons from COVID-19
Notable Quotes: I fear for our future. Should this Bill be legislated, it will change the course of our society towards a darker age where we no longer celebrate democracy nor encourage rigorous public debate on issues.
The meaning of the terms 'misinformation' and 'disinformation' is entirely subjective.
In a democracy, individuals will never agree with each other all the time on all issues. It is this diversity of thought that makes our society stronger.
